title: The Magic of Sherry in Jerez
paragraphs: Text size
The town of Jerez de la Frontera, about an hour’s drive south of Seville in the region of Andalucía in southern Spain, is a magical one.

There’s a palpable aura as you walk down its zig-zagging cobblestone streets. With such a concentration of warehouses, or bodegas, in one spot, sherry is quite literally all around you—a wonderful, rich aroma seemingly moving with you from one block to the next.

It’s a place where the industry for a time grew larger than the town. “We reached a point where the city just had to grow around it,” says Simon Leth-Nissen, international brand manager for sherry producer González Byass. Consider that in 1855, the company accounted for 2% of Spain’s exports—not wine exports, but all products.
Indeed, Jerez de la Frontera is the home and heart of sherry.
What is Sherry?

Sherry is a Spanish fortified wine, and the city of Jerez is actually one point of the “sherry triangle,” a collection of three towns, including Sanlúcar de Barrameda and El Puerto de Santa María, in which the whole of the sherry industry is contained.

The industry has had its ups and downs, and as a result today it’s perhaps best known for its role in the maturation of whisky. That’s a cruel injustice to this complex and beguiling fortified wine, a prestigious product made by a proud people with quality and care, and built on the foundation of centuries of history. A visit to Jerez is perhaps the only way to fully appreciate the category.

“You have to be here—smell the air. Look, touch, see how deep it runs here,” says Mario Muñoz González, a portfolio manager for the sherry producer Lustau. At Lustau, that might mean observing the thick spider webs entombing some of its casks—the spiders protecting the wood from pests—as you wander cool, damp warehouses, buildings positioned in particular alignment to properly capitalize on favorable breezes.
A beguiling fortified wine, sherry is prestigious product made by a proud people with quality and care, and built on the foundation of centuries of history. Jake Emen
Styles of Sherry
With sherry production, there’s a limited collection of grapes to work with. “We are rather lucky here in Jerez because we can only use three varieties,” Leth-Nissen says.

Those three grapes include Palomino Fino, Moscatel, and Pedro Ximénez, though Palomino makes up 95% of production. But sherry is still remarkably varied, depending on how the maturation is accomplished and for how long, where the wine comes from, and the strength and sweetness of the wine.

The most important distinction may be in understanding the difference between what sherry producers call biological aging versus oxidative aging. Biological aging occurs when the sherry wine within a barrel is contained under a film of yeast on the surface known as flor. Fino is a dry sherry made from the Palomino Fino grape, aged entirely under flor for a minimum of two years. “Tio Pepe is a classic Fino, our flag bearer, and the most sold sherry in the world,” Leth-Nissen says.

Manzanilla sherry is made in the same way, but hails only from Sanlúcar de Barrameda, one of the three points of the triangle. “Finos and Manzanilla are the same in every way except for the location it’s being aged,” Muñoz González says.

“The Amontillado is a development of the Fino,” Leth-Nissen says. If you continue to age Fino long enough, eventually the yeast can’t survive due to the higher alcohol levels present. Alternatively, producers can also shave years off the process by refortifying the wine to kill off the yeast directly after an initial period spent under flor. The maturation spent without flor is known as oxidative, and Amontillado therefore undergoes both.

Oloroso sherry is fortified at the start to a level which won’t support the yeast, therefore undergoing entirely oxidative aging. All of the above, a huge range of styles, is entirely based off a single grape. “It’s all the Palomino grape, with the differences based on the decisions we make along the way,” Leth-Nissen says.

Palo Cortado, meanwhile, has a mysterious origin, essentially as a Fino gone wrong, with the flor dying off before maturation is finished. (Fluctuations in humidity or temperature, or incorrectly estimating alcohol content and therefore over-fortifying the wine, are all ways the flor could be killed accidentally).
Jamie Gonzalez, proprietor of the family-run Bodegas Faustino Gonzalez, producer of the Cruz Vieja line of sherry. Jake Emen

“The real Palo Cortado is one you cannot make,” says Jamie González, proprietor of the family-run Bodegas Faustino González, producer of the Cruz Vieja line of sherry. “It’s an oenological accident. That's the real Palo Cortado.”

The phrase palo cortado means “cut stick,” referring to the marks a producer would make on a barrel to indicate what he was storing inside. A single vertical line represented Fino, but when the flor would die off, a horizontal line was made slicing across it, cutting or canceling what had been a Fino.

In modern practice, Palo Cortado is of course purposefully made, and it need not always begin its life under the flor. “Today, the only regulation is that it is supposed to have an elegant fine nose like the Amontillado but a more structured palate like the Oloroso,” Leth-Nissen says.
For me, it’s from the family Oloroso,” González says. “When you have a very old Oloroso and a very old Palo Cortado it’ hard to tell the difference.”

Finally, it’s time to consider the other grapes. Medium, or cream, sherries are blends of Palomino with PX or Moscatel grapes; the more of the latter two varieties are added, the sweeter the resulting wine. Sherry can also be made entirely from Pedro Ximénez or Moscatel. And these are some of the sweetest wines in the world,” Leth-Nissen says.
The Mathematical Magic of the Solera

Regardless of the type of sherry being produced, the solera is fundamental to its development. Wines of different ages are mingled together, the old wines providing depth, the young wines providing vibrancy, and the ongoing process offering an inimitable, consistent house style for a particular sherry.
“The solar system is the beginning and the end of everything in Jerez,” Muñoz González says. “It’s less magical and more mathematical, actually.”

The solera is technically the bottom row of a three or four-level stack of barrels. The barrels in the solera, containing the oldest wines, are never entirely emptied. Instead, a portion generally between 25% and 33% is removed for bottling, and replaced with wine from the next oldest row of barrels above it in the first criadera, which is refilled with wine from the second criadera, which is topped off by the sobretablas, the freshly fortified wine from the latest harvest.

This creates wines with average ages rather than coming from specific harvests or vintages. Certain producers, though, including both González Byass and Lustau, do offer vintage sherries in tiny amounts accounting for about 1% of production.
At Lustau, thick spider webs entomb some of its casks-the spiders protecting the wood from pests. Jake Emen
Reinvigorating the Market
“The solera delivers the same quality, the same consistency, the same personality,” Muñoz González says.

That stability is crucial, though in modern days, it’s actually somewhat of a hindrance in the wine world, a market often powered by the limited supply of exceptional releases. Producers are starting to offer rarer and more limited offerings, such as Tio Pepe En Rama from González Byass. En rama essentially translates to “raw,” which makes these sherries as near an approximation to drinking from the barrel as possible. “It basically means the wine doesn’t go through filtration or stabilization,” Leth-Nissen says. “It’s the closest to what you get to the natural state of Tio Pepe.”

The annual spring release began a decade ago, with a few dozen casks hand-selected by master blender Antonio Flores. “We also see a new concept for sherry with Tio Pepe En Rama, the concept of bottle aging,” says Silvia Flores, Antonio’s daughter who’s now an assistant winemaker with the company. “The wine continues to develop over time.”

At Faustino González, all of the sherries Jamie produces are en rama. “It’s all en rama, it’s more natural,” González says. “We are real artisans. We don't make wines. I only care for and select wines. Wine is natural.”

That doesn’t mean he hasn’t ventured into the realm of premium, limited releases. In 2018, he released the Cruz Vieja Oloroso Muy Vieja, a highly limited release of only 120 bottles taken from a three-barrel solera system over a century in age. It’s only the second time Faustino González has made it available, following a similarly scantly-sized offering in 1996. “It’s entirely singular,” González says, “this is for meditation.”
